author: Dr. David Martinez (ED)
note_text:
HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
48 y/o female with poorly controlled DM2 (HbA1c 9.2%). Presents with 3 days of right lower leg redness, swelling, and warmth. Reports minor scratch from shaving 5 days ago. Denies fever at home. No prior cellulitis.

PHYSICAL EXAM:
Right lower leg with 12x8cm area of erythema, warmth, mild edema. No crepitus, no bullae, no purulent drainage. Borders marked. Mild tenderness to palpation.

ED COURSE:
Afebrile in ED (100.2F). WBC mildly elevated at 13.2. Lactate normal. Blood glucose 285, started insulin drip.

MEDICAL DECISION MAKING:
Cellulitis of right lower extremity in diabetic patient.

Considerations:
1. Failed oral antibiotics - Patient did NOT try oral antibiotics prior
2. Diabetes may impair healing
3. No systemic signs of sepsis
4. Cellulitis area moderate but not rapidly spreading

PLAN:
Admit to Medicine (Inpatient).
IV Ancef.
Glycemic control.
Elevate extremity.
Mark borders and monitor for spread.
